post.title: 2011 Resolution Follow Up
post.author: abelgaxiola
post.excerpt: One of my three part New Year’s resolution was to get familiar with ASP.NET MVC. I have for the past month been working on my spare time migrating a website from standard ASP.NET to the MVC architecture using MVC2.
post.content:
One of my three part New Year’s resolution was to get familiar with ASP.NET MVC.  I have for the past month been working on my spare time migrating a website from standard ASP.NET to the MVC architecture using MVC2.  The process has been slow but I feel that I’ve learned a lot in the process.  In the meantime, while working on the website migration a few other technologies that I’ve been reading about (mostly in blogs) were officially released; they were: ASP.NET MVC3, WebMatrix, and Orchard, to name a few.  Since my resolution is mostly about staying up-to-date with technology (mostly for the MS stack since that is where I spend most of my time) I decided to take a look at what the noise was about.  If you are interested in some of the technologies I just mentioned take a look at the following blog entry by Scott Gu: Blog Entry for January 13

Since one of the technologies I have been learning is MVC2 I decided to move forward and take a look at MVC3 and have to say that it is impressive.  I was also impressed with WebMatrix and how easy it is to create and publish some pretty complex sites, as well as some simple ones.  Orchard impressed me the most and I created a sample website on my workstation that I felt had promise; but when it was published it was a different story (my hosting provider is godaddy).  Accessing and navigating the site was slower than acceptable and so I took it off after spending hours trying to make it load faster  — too bad because I was hoping to use it for one of my sites.

In the mean time I have been playing with MVC3 and have published a site built using VS 2010’s MVC3 website template.  I created a sandbox site that I intend to use for testing and trying new technologies. Right now there is only one site but I intend to use it for other experiments.  I will share my successes as well as my failures in this blog, and maybe my experiences will be of benefit to someone else.
